captions.text: - I'M PROUD OF YOU.

CAN WE TALK ABOUT
THE SCIENTOLOGY THING
JUST FOR A MINUTE?

- CERTAINLY.
- ALL RIGHT.

- SHOULD I SIT LIKE THIS,
THOUGH?
- HOWEVER YOU WANT TO SIT.

IT'S A MYSTERIOUS--YOU KNOW,
SCIENTOLOGY.
THERE'S THIS KIND OF THING

THAT NOBODY KNOWS ANYTHING
ABOUT IT.

AND NOW YOU'RE NOT
IN THAT RELIGION ANYMORE,

AND I GUESS THE ONE QUESTION IS,
WHY DID YOU CHOOSE TO LEAVE?
IF YOU CAN ANSWER THAT.
- WELL, UM, YOU KNOW,

MY MOTHER GOT INVOLVED
WHEN WE WERE VERY YOUNG,
SO IT'S ALL WE REALLY EVER KNEW.
BUT OVER TIME, MY EYES OPENED,

AND I JUST COULD NO LONGER BE
AFFILIATED WITH THE ORGANIZATION

AND MY FAMILY FELT THE SAME,
SO WE LEFT.
- MM-HMM.
AND IS IT--NOW--AND HOW ARE YOU?

'CAUSE I HEAR IT'S DIFFERENT
THAN LEAVING ANOTHER RELIGION,
SO IS IT--ARE YOU OKAY?
YOU CAN DRINK.
[laughter]

- I'M OKAY.
YEAH, I'M OKAY.

TO ANSWER YOUR QUESTION,
IT WAS--YOU KNOW, IT'S HARD,
AND WE'RE--WE'VE LOST FRIENDS

THAT CAN NO LONGER
TALK TO US

WHO ARE STILL
IN THE ORGANIZATION, BUT...
- NOW, THAT IS A THING?

WHEN YOU LEAVE A CHURCH, YOU
CAN'T--THEY CAN'T TALK TO YOU

OR YOU CAN'T TALK TO THEM
OR SOMETHING?

- CORRECT.
- WOW.

- AND THESE ARE FRIENDS
THAT WE'VE HAD
FOR, YOU KNOW, DOZENS OF YEARS,

BUT I HAVE GREAT FRIENDS,
OTHER FRIENDS

THAT ARE NOT IN THE CHURCH
THAT HAVE STOOD BY US,
AND OUR FAMILY IS STRONGER.

WE'RE TOGETHER,
AND THAT'S ALL I CAN ASK FOR.

- YOU HAVE ME.
I'M YOUR FRIEND.

WE'RE YOUR FRIENDS.
- THANK YOU.
[cheers and applause]

- ALL RIGHT, WE'LL TAKE A BREAK.
WE'LL BE RIGHT BACK.
MORE WITH LEAH.
[no audible dialogue]

comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
+Wolf Larson I don't "suspect" they are unhappy, I know they are unhappy. 
It's not my "opinion" that it's a cult, it's a fact that it's a cult. And 
I'm not on a mission to make them quit as I've already said I've given up 
on that because I don't want to push them away. I don't know why you've 
been insisting on digging into my personal life only to judge it so harshly 
when you don't even know me *or* my parents.
comments.author: catpower

comments.text:
So you suspect they are unhappy and in your opinion the establishment is a 
cult. Yet your family remains diligent. Not the soundest of opinions I have 
encountered. But good luck on your mission of trying to make them quit.
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
+Wolf Larson They both had really abusive childhoods and my dad never 
really dealt with his, and he's been majorly depressed about it for years. 
My mom has managed to move on from hers and while she's not as miserable as 
my dad is, I can tell she's just not happy. Maybe not depressed, but 
definitely not happy.
comments.author: catpower

comments.text: Why are they not happy? Did they tell you this?
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text: +Wolf Larson They're definitely not happy, but yeah.
comments.author: catpower

comments.text:
+catpower Sounds like they are happy doing what they do. Yeah I would lay 
off it as well they seem to be happy.
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
+Wolf Larson They don't want my help because they don't believe it's a 
cult, so therefore they don't think they *need* any help. I'm no expert on 
the matter so I probably haven't gone about this the right way, but I've 
tried helping by explaining to them that it was a cult and telling them why 
it's so important to me that they leave. I've also told my mother how 
scared I am for her and the rest of my family and I've tried to show her 
that this is not a normal religion, but like I said, she doesn't believe 
me. There isn't a whole lot more I can do, because if I try too hard then 
they're going to start resenting me. I'm lucky enough that they didn't kick 
me out after I left the cult, and I'd rather not push my luck any further, 
so I've decided to keep my mouth shut now and just hope one day they'll get 
out.
comments.author: catpower

comments.text:
+MolecularMoonlight Thank you for your comment, and yes there are support 
groups online but I've found they aren't really helping me all that much 
unfortunately. My parents are working on getting me a therapist for other 
reasons though, so hopefully he'll be able to help me out. I'll check out 
Gloria's talks. I've never heard of her before. I'm glad she was able to 
help you, hopefully she'll help me too :)
comments.author: catpower

comments.text:
+catpower How come they don't want your help? What kind of help do you

comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
There might be support groups online for survivors of cults, maybe even 
your specific cult. You could chat with them. It might be useful to you.

 For me, Gloria Steniem (her talks are on youtube) really helped me get out 
of the head space of my oppressive religious christian family (not a cult, 
but oppressive like one). She helped encourage me to empower myself & it's 
refreshing to hear someone say the words you need to hear that you thought 
only you were thinking. For me, those words were about women being equal to 
men ~ and not subservient to men, as christianity demands. It's like the 
healthy, balanced voice you wish was your mother's. Hope you check both 
ideas out. Wish you & your family well! :0)
comments.author: MolecularMoonlight

comments.text:

comments.author: Roger Hornaday

comments.text: And you, likewise.
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
+Wolf Larson I feel satisfied I've stated my points clearly. All I wish to 
say to you is, "go in peace".
comments.author: Roger Hornaday

comments.text:
He never claims it is some special insight. This is simply an observation 
of the obvious. You would be surprised how many people don't understand the 
obvious. From your above description it appears you agree with this. And 
allowing someone to have their own opinions on a subject as you stated is 
exactly how reality is described. You don't think this data can help 
someone?
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
+Wolf Larson  "Reality" is just another word for "conditioning". It's how 
we are shaped by our experiences. What we like and dislike is determined by 
our social or biological conditioning, that is "affinity".  Communication 
is the means  by which intelligent organisms convey information. 
 UNDERSTANDING is the knowledge that we are all essentially the same. If I 
have that knowledge then I can bypass ARC as a means to achieving 
understanding. People in general try to bridge their differences by 
focusing on common causes and interests. This is because people have the 
knowledge, they understand, that it's usually better when we don't fight 
with each other.  Hubbard's ARC theory, for all the trumpets blaring, is 
not a special insight and it doesn't lead to people getting along with each 
other any better than they ever did before his theory.
comments.author: Roger Hornaday

comments.text:
Its actually very quite simple. Here is an example. Two people dont get 
along, they dont see eye to eye. Like you and me for example. We each have 
a different reality on this subject. Therefore our affinity is quite low 
(liking). Let say we continue talking and find some things we agree on, 
could be anything. If we were to start talking about this new subject that 
we agree on our affinity would increase. Thats all it is. We now understand 
each other, we are on the same page. It is no more complicated than that. 
Any upset that exists can be found to be in a break of one of those three 
points. Any.
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
+Wolf Larson I conceded ARC theory is a serviceable if simplistic 
explanation for human relationships. But it isn't the formula for 
understanding in general. By failing to be precise in his language, Hubbard 
puffs up the scope of his theory to include ALL understanding. That was my 
point. I never used the words, "evil lie" that is a misrepresentation. 
 "How do you expect to understand someone without getting their reality?" 
 What does it mean to UNDERSTAND somebody and what is meant by their 
"REALITY"? And what is the importance of this understanding?  My assertion 
about Hubbard and his "tech" is that it is all based upon unexamined 
generalities. It all falls apart when you start analyzing it.
comments.author: Roger Hornaday

comments.text:
What? Lol. To how could you ever expect to understand someone without 
getting their reality. This can only be done through communication. 
Communication is the building block of human relations. You say knowledge 
is done through study. Study is communication with your environment. Its a 
no wonder you think this is an evil lie. You have misunderstandings. Sorry 
for being too frisky i'm just sleepy right now.
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
+Wolf Larson Hubbard defined ARC as the three things that make up 
UNDERSTANDING. ARC may be one of many reasonably accurate ways to break 
down human to human amicability in relationships but Hubbard said ARC is 
the make-up of understanding, just understanding.  That would have to 
include understanding not just individual people but humans as a group, 
understanding chemistry, understanding how to build a house, etc. The scope 
of ARC is less than he makes it appear. Understanding is based on knowledge 
and confidence in that knowledge. Even within the limited scope of human 
relationships, ARC is a simplistic formula hardly meriting singular 
distinction.
comments.author: Roger Hornaday

comments.text:
Okay, ill take one of your examples. ARC triangle. Composing of Affinity, 
reality and communication. The concept is that communicating is a very 
important aspect to understanding someone. Through communicating you gain a 
reality (agreements) and affinity (love or liking) will increase. Basic 
tool to help in social problems. Are you sure that is a lie. It sounds like 
common sense to me, something that many people lack.
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
+Wolf Larson What was A lie he wrote in a book? Singular?  You want just 
ONE? You're easy to please.  Then we'll skip the nonsensical axioms, and 
glide on past his false definition of power and his erroneous concept of 
understanding (ARC), we'll turn a blind eye toward his preposterous notion 
about the value of admiration (calling it "the most valued particle"). 
 We'll just go straight to the boss of all his lies.  I'm talking about his 
lie known as the state of "CLEAR".  There is no such thing and there never 
was.  Of course there's no such thing as "OT" either but that goes without 
saying.
comments.author: Roger Hornaday

comments.text: Well you read the books. So then tell me what was a lie he wrote in a book?
comments.author: Wolf Larson

comments.text:
Many religions ask for a tithe or donation, but Scientology requires you to 
pay before you can "advance" to the next spiritual level.  If wealthy

can't leave Scientology without threats being made against you is what sets 
it apart as a cult.
comments.author: MsNooneinparticular

comments.text:
ANY religion *can* be a money making scam.

Your sentence was a little off. You are also considering "organized" 
religions, instead of those that are a part of one's culture and day to day 
life and not built in ritualistic demands and fees. 

That being said, Scientology us the best at it, yes Christianity probably 
has duped more over the years and made more money, but Scientology has one 
center head for the most part; it strictly conditions the people and mind 
rapes them. If you watch anime you may get this simile, Scientology is like 
Geass while other religions who take advantage you are like 
Tysukyomi...while they both are jacked up and the latter causes more pain, 
Geass makes you a complete zombie and slave that goes against your will 
completely.

See, that's something that bugs me everytime. How sincere is Ellen when she 
says something like "I'm your friend" at the end of the interview? Would 
she actually do anything that a real friend would do and hold up to the 
promise? Or does she just say these words in front of many cameras to make 
herself seem more likeable? Because everybody is going like "Aaaaw, she's 
her friend. How nice of her!" But is it? Is it nice of someone to tell them 
"I'm your friend" to their face" and then not behaving like one? I know I'm 
being suspicious here. And I know I might be wrong. It's just something to 
think about.﻿

Scientology are perpetrated by the ORGANIZATION, not individuals. In fact, 
many individuals within the Church of Scientology are innocent people who 
wish only to improve themselves. The actions that the organization's upper 
management does - physical beatings, enforcing policies of excommunication, 
attacking a person's character to whoever leaves - what kind of a 
"religion" hires private investigators? Am glad Leah left

comments.text:
Yes, but what the fuck does the history of any other religion relate to

comments.text:
I am not attempting to excuse anything. However, the wrongs of Scientology

discrimination, and religious oppression brought about by several 
establishments of the Christian faith. Even worse, the extremists of the 
religion are still oppressing people today. It is only recently that others 
have begun to emerge from such tyranny. Scientology may have become a cult, 
but Christianity has for centuries been a global dictatorship.

comments.text:
She didn't ask precisely because she's a good host. Being a host doesn't 
mean you have to only satisfy the audience but also try to make your guest 
as comfortable as possible. Of course politeness, common sense, courtesy 
and sensibility towards such a scandalous topic are necessary, she just 
didn't want make her feel she's being preyed on but rather to be supportive 
and let her know she's backing her up.
comments.author: Gil CJ

comments.text:
Scientology is not a religion. During the 1950s, L. Ron Hubbard undertook a 
project of "religious cloaking", turning a system that had been promoted as 
a secular "science of mental health" into a religion through minor changes, 
such as referring to Scientology personnel as "ministers." This process has 
been detailed by former Scientologists. Furthermore, Scientology meets 
several characteristics of a cult, as defined by FACTNet.
comments.author: OpenComments

comments.text:
Scientology is not a religion, it is a moneymaking company founded by 
failed science fiction writer L. Ron Hubbard, whose stated purpose was to 
create a religion that would "make money," and whose paranoiac delusions 
were codified within the articles of the organization. The company uses 
classic mind control techniques to brainwash its followers, neutralize 
their personalities and minimize the risk of dissent.
comments.author: OpenComments

comments.text:
Granted, they tried - they attempted to have google remove web page search

comments.author: OpenComments

comments.text:
The Church of Scientology has always had a reputation of abusing the law to 
destroy those that criticize it. Time Magazine made an article "The 
Thriving Cult of Greed and Power" , and Scientology sued them. Scientology 
lost, but it still cost Time Magazine millions of dollars. The BBC released 
a documentary "Scientology and Me" - Scientology made their own 
counterdocumentary riddled with ad hominem. Enter the internet - the only 
place this cult can't suppress information from.
comments.author: OpenComments
